channel.title: Comments on: MySQL Cluster running on Raspberry Pi
channel.description: Database technologies - especially around scalability and High Availability

item.title: By: Mikael RonstrÃ¶m
item.dc:creator: Mikael RonstrÃ¶m
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/mysql-cluster/mysql-cluster-running-on-raspberry-pi#comment-659345">changs</a>.
MySQL Cluster 8.0.18 now compiles on ARM CPUs and there is a community version for ARM on Red Hat.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to changs.

MySQL Cluster 8.0.18 now compiles on ARM CPUs and there is a
community version for ARM on Red Hat.

item.title: By: changs
item.dc:creator: changs
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/mysql-cluster/mysql-cluster-running-on-raspberry-pi#comment-446383">Sebastian</a>.
Hi Sebastian I have the same error as you, 'rmb was not declared in this scope',could you tell me your solution? thank you very munch.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Sebastian.

Hi Sebastian
I have the same error as you, ‘rmb was not declared in this scope’,could you tell me your solution?
thank you very munch.

item.title: By: Damian
item.dc:creator: Damian
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/mysql-cluster/mysql-cluster-running-on-raspberry-pi#comment-446383">Sebastian</a>.
Hi Sebastian, Forgot which version it was, but it was ndb. It was stable for basic playing around. I didn't invest more time into it due to low RAM on the PI. However, I just picked up 10 PI 2s, so will try to do 8 node cluster (paired with another 8 nodes on the xen for redundancy) I currently use 2x4 set up with 4 old laptops (1GB ram each) and 4 VMs. PI 2s come with 1GB or ram so might get somewhere with that.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Sebastian.

Hi Sebastian,
Forgot which version it was, but it was ndb. It was stable for basic playing around. I didn’t invest more time into it due to low RAM on the PI.
However, I just picked up 10 PI 2s, so will try to do 8 node cluster (paired with another 8 nodes on the xen for redundancy)
I currently use 2×4 set up with 4 old laptops (1GB ram each) and 4 VMs. PI 2s come with 1GB or ram so might get somewhere with that.

item.content:encoded:
In reply to Damian.

Hi Damian

Could you share with us some information about stability of your solution to error: ‘rmb was not declared in this scope’

item.title: By: Damian
item.dc:creator: Damian
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/mysql-cluster/mysql-cluster-running-on-raspberry-pi#comment-78540">Damian</a>.
Hi Andrew,
Did some more digging, and this turns out to be the "memory barrier" assembly functions, wich are only defined for the x86 architecture. w and r stand for write and read respectively. I got around the problem by bascially commenting out these calls in the mt.cpp . Not sure how stable/reliable this will make the ndb, but at least it compiled and it is working.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Damian.

Hi Andrew,

Did some more digging, and this turns out to be the “memory barrier” assembly functions, wich are only defined for the x86 architecture. w and r stand for write and read respectively.
I got around the problem by bascially commenting out these calls in the mt.cpp . Not sure how stable/reliable this will make the ndb, but at least it compiled and it is working.

item.content:encoded:

item.title: By: Damian
item.dc:creator: Damian
item.description:
Hello,
I keep getting compile errors at the storage/ndb/src/kernel/mv/mt.cpp step. (About 45% into the compile process). Errors are wmb, mb, rmb was not declared in this scope. Any ideas?
item.content:encoded:
Hello,

I keep getting compile errors at the storage/ndb/src/kernel/mv/mt.cpp step. (About 45% into the compile process). Errors are wmb, mb, rmb was not declared in this scope.
Any ideas?
